Title:
Morphological and molecular evidences for two new species
within Russula subg. Brevipes from China
Keywords:
Russulales, Russulaceae, ectomycorrhizal fungi, phylogeny,
taxonomy
Abstract:
Two Russula species, R. subbrevipes and R.
callainomarginis spp. nov., are described from China based on
morphological and molecular characters. R. subbrevipes has only been
found at altitudes of higher than 3400 m in south-western China so far
and is characterised by the yellow ochre pileal surface, glabrous or
tomentose stipe, fruity odour, subglobose to ellipsoid basidiospores
(7.69.4 ´ 6.48 µm), isolated or partial connected warts and
pleurocystidia with a cap appendage. R. callainomarginis is
characterised by cream to white pileus, light turquoise lamellae margin,
spongy stipe, light turquoise zone on the top of stipe, pungent odour,
globose to ellipsoid basidiospores (6.48.3 ´ 5.77.4 µm) and dominant
isolated warts. The phylogeny of Russula is reconstructed with
multi-gene sequences including the internal transcribed spacer regions
(ITS), the large subunit (nrLSU), the small subunit of the mitochondrial
rRNA gene (mtSSU), and the second subunit of RNA polymerase II (RPB2).
The results show that both R. subbrevipes and R. callainomarginis
represent new lineages in Russula subg. Brevipes. Illustrated
descriptions of the two new species are presented.
